critique: The document establishes the National Youth Administration (NYA) during the Great Depression, focusing on providing relief and employment for youth. It expands executive power by authorizing the Executive Director to appoint officers and employees without regard to civil service laws and fix compensation without regard to the Classification Act. It also centralizes power at the federal level, establishing a national program administered by a federal agency. The program aims to provide relief and work for young people, indicating a focus on social inclusion and economic intervention.
